titleStmt.title: Corpus of Transcribed Mixtepec-Mixtec Spoken Language
titleStmt.author: author

Paster, M., 2004. A phonological sketch of the Yucanani Mixtepec dialect of Mixtec. In Lea Harper and Carmen Jany (Ed.), Proceedings of the 7th Annual Workshop on American Indian Languages (pp. 61-76). UC Santa Barbara.

Paster, Mary and Beam de Azcona, Rosemary. 2004a. Aspects of tone in Yucunany Mixtepec Mixtec. In Lea Harper and Carmen Jany (Ed.), Proceedings of the 7th Annual Workshop on American Indian Languages (pp. 61-76). UC Santa Barbara.

Paster, M. and Beam de Azcona, Rosemary. 2004b. Aspects of tone in the Yucunany dialect of Mixtepec Mixtec. Paper presented at the Conference on Otomanguean and Oaxacan Languages, University ofCalifornia, Berkeley.
Paster, M. 2005. Tone Rules in Yucanani Mixtepec Mixtec. SSILA meeting (p. 13). Oakland: SSILA.
Paster, M., 2007. The origin of (Apparent) Avoidance of homophony in Yucanany Mixtepec dialect of Mixtec., Proceedings of American Indian Languages (August, 17). UCLA.

div.p: 1. Introduction Mary Paster and Rosemary Beam de Azcona UC Berkeley In this paper, we present a sketch of the phonology of the Yucunany dialect of Mixtepec Mixtec in terms of its segmental and tonal inventories as well as some phonological processes that we have observed. The Mixtepec Mixtec language is spoken by 12,000 people (Ethnologue, 2004). The speech community sits on the border between the Mixteca Alta and Mixteca Baja areas. The language is spoken in San Juan Mixtepec and many smaller surrounding towns in the ex-districts of Juxtlahuaca and Tlaxiaco. Previous discussions of Mixtepec Mixtec are found in Pike and Ibach (1978) and Josserand (1983). Throughout the paper, we refer to the 'couplet', which is a common term for the structure of Mixtec roots (see, for example, Josserand 1983), since roots contain exactly two vowels. In Mixtepec Mixtec, root shape is as shown below:

div.ab:
(1) (C)(C)V(C)V
2. Segments
2.1 Consonants
2.1.1 Consonant inventory The phonemic consonantal inventory of Mixtepec Mixtec is shown below. The symbols used reflect the practical orthography devised by our Berkeley Mixtec working group. Symbols in parentheses represent phonemes that are marginally used in the language and/or occur only in loanwords.

2) Consonantal inventory
Manner Bilabial Dental Alveolar Palatal(ized) Retroflex Velar Labiovelar
Stop/affricate (p) t tz (ty) ch k kw
Fricative s x G) v z g
Nasal m n fi
Liquid 1, (r, rr) Glide (w) y 2.1.2 Labial variation We have observed multiple allophones of the /v/ phoneme: [v], [13], and [b]. [v] is the most common, occurring invariably in word-initial position, as in vilu [villi] 'cat'. 'XTAIL 2004 62 A phollological Jkelch ~//he YJlC/(f/(/f!}' dialed o/Mix/epee AIL'dec Word-medially, especially following a glottal stop, we have observed the [b] and W] allophones occurring interchangeably with [v], as in the word ll'va [u?ba] - [u?0a] - [u?va] 'salty'. 2.1.3 Phonotactic constraints on consonants Consonants are restricted to onsets in Mixtepec' Mixtec. We have found only one word containing a coda consonant, and it is a loanword: arrooz 'rice' Spanish arroz. Consonant clusters do not occur root-medially. They may occur word-initially or word-medially where prefixes concatenate with roots. The following clusters are attested:

(3) Nasal + stop or affricate Inti [nd] nducha Intmsl [ndz] ndzikii IntmSl [ndm3] nchaa Ink! [IJg] kllnga '4 InkWI [IJgW] ngwii lsi + stop 1st! Isk! Iskwl staa skita Skwiia lSI + consonant IStmSI xchaa ISn! Ndixnuuu 'goat' 's/he walked' 'blue' 'we will talk (to somebody), 'fox' 'tortilla' 'run!' 'Santiago Juxtlahuaca' 'tomorrow' 'Heroica Ciudad de Tlaxiaco'

2.1.4 Loan and marginal consonants The loan and marginal consonants of Mixtepec Mixtec are as follows. First, we have found Ipl only in loanwords such as pail 'rebozo' Spanishpaiio 'kerchief. Irl also occurs in loanwords, including [urru 'donkey' Spanish burro 'donkey'. We have found Ixl only in loanwords such as the name Jwaaa 'Juan.' Ir/ occurs in both Spanish loanwords and in the third person masculine respectful pronoun -raa, which may be a loan of unknown origin; Coathm-Loxicha Zapotec has a third person human informal pronoun ar. The phoneme Iwl occurs only in function words, such as the first person
Mwy Paster and Rosemary Beam de Azcona 63
2.2 Vowels
2.2.1 Vowel inventory The vowel phonemes of Mixtepec Mixtec are shown below. This is a canonical five-vowel system with widely dispersed vowels.
(4) V owe Inventory Front Central Back High 1 u Mid e 0 Low a
Each of these vowels has a nasalized counterpart. Although the vowels' duration varies contextually (for example, vowels bearing a contour tone are somewhat longer than vowels bearing a level tone), vowel length is not phonologically contrastive.
2.2.2 Vowel distribution The vowels Iii, lui, 101, and Ia! occur regularly throughout the language, but the lei vowel is rare, occurring in few words. One instance of lei is found in ve'e 'house'. Although each of the vowels shown in (4) has a nasalized counterpart, 10/, and le~1 are rare. Some examples are shown below (nasalization is indicated in our orthography via underlining):
(5) nakQ'Q 'let's go!' kwiee'slow' The nasalized vowels /to/, taJ, and luol are common, as in the examples below.
(6) IT 'one' Jwaaa 'Juan' nitu 'face' iii kg'q chy. '1£ 'skin' 'talk! ' 'spider' iiii! 'six' tzg'i! 'fifteen' (zelny. 'brother's wife' Interestingly, a majority of monomorphemic words in Mixtepec Mixtec have the same vowel in both syllables. This could be due to a historical vowel harmony process, though no such process exists as part of the synchronic phonology. There are apparently no diphthongs in the language. In the rare examples containing non-identical adjacent vowels (e.g., pail 'rebozo '), the vowels belong to different syllables. We have not found any couplets with three different vowels not separated by consonants; such a couplet would probably have to be analyzed as having a diphthong since, as mentioned above, couplets contain exactly two syllables. ""\Xi'" AIL 2004 64 3. Suprasegmentals 3.1 Tone 3.1.1 Tone inventory
A phollological sketch of 'he YII(f{IICl1!Y dialed ~lMi:,:tepec A11~Yte, Mixtepec Mixtec has a three-tone system. The tonal inventory, as exemplified below, includes High (H), Mid (M), and Low (L) tones. In our orthography, H tone is represented by an acute accent, L tone by a grave accent, and M tone is not marked. Since vowel length is not contrastive, in our orthography we use additional vowels as needed to accommodate tone markings for contour tones.
(7) L ch£l£l 'star' tzat£l 'spicy' ndaa 'flat' lily 'six' M aa 'yes' luu 'little' uu 'yes' li 'one' H nchcui 'blue' vi/it 'cat' ii. 'hail' kani 'female turkey'
3.1.2 Tone patterns on mono morphemic couplets Couplets exhibit a maximum of three tones. The observed one-, two-, and threetone patterns on couplets are shown below.
(8) L M H LM CVV CVCV CVV CVCV CVV CVCV CVV CVCV ch£l£l 'star' ndaa 'flat' sow 'shoulder' £lvi 'two' ngwii 'fox' luu 'little' mula 'mule' yachi 'near' nchdd 'blue' kOla 'male turkey' kani 'female turkey' chaa 'man' n-a, ,a 'thing' tzelng 'brother's wife' titzi 'stomach' "'\Xl" .AIL 2004 II tzg'y s£lt£l £ltza 'nine' 'fifteen' 'priest' 'seven' ve'e 'house' g'g 'five' machu'mule' nchd'd'salsa' lachi 'vulture' nditchd 'goat' kaa 'metal' so'o 'ear' tika 'cricket' yucha 'river'
Mary Paster and Rosemary Beam de Azeona 65
LH cvv staa 'tortilla' nill' 'face' koo 'snake' ko'o 'plate'
CVCV
kumi 'four , nama 'soap' Izalll 'coffin' savi 'rain'
MH CVV yo ' 0,'rope' ehe'e 'cute' ehy. 'll. 'spider' na 'a 'woman'
CVCV yala 'old'
HM CVV xi 'a 'hawk'
CVCV Izoko 'possum' Izika 'far' nani 'brother' kci'nu 'big
HL CVV
ehtii 'chair' kwa'a'red' cha'a 'short' ncha'i 'black'
CVCV not attested
ML CVV yoo 'drinking vessel' saa 'bird'
CVCV xito 'uncle' tutu 'paper' , , yu va 'ice' u'va 'salty'
LML CVV xaaa 'chin' xioo 'dress, skirt'
CVCV ndaaku 'broom'
LHM cvv tzaaa 'new'
CVCV yooso 'metate' yuuti 'sand' kiltisa 'sister's husband' filchi 'avocado'
MLH CVV viii 'healthy-looking'
CVCV yosoo 'grassy plain' I.X U" 'hair' tikwaa 'orange' ikii 'squash'
MHM CVV Skwiia 'Santiago Juxtlahuaca'
CVCV kotoo 'sarape'
HML cvv Jwaaa 'Juan' « Spanish) pail 'rebozo ,
CVCV yukuu 'yoke' « Sp.yugo) anaa 'heart' Minaa 'Los Tejocotes' sukuu 'high' « Sp. mina 'mine')
HLH CVV chiil 'fingernail' iii 'skin' kwiil 'narrow' kwiii 'green'
CVCV xiini 'hat'
"\X7 AIL 2004 66 1 phoflologiml sketch ofhe ) '''aIlI(Jf!)' dialed q ll'1i ...... lepe( Mi:\:/et
Note that not all possible combinations of three tones are observed. Some generalizations regarding the gaps in the set of tone patterns on couplets are as follows. First, we do not find patterns with two adjacent instances of the same tone (e.g. *HHL, where the first syllable is H-toned and the second has a HL falling tone)!. We can rule out such patterns via a version of the Obligatory Contour Principle, which bans adjacent identical tone specifications, applying to underlying forms.· However, we must also rule out some couplets with multiply linked underlying tones to avoid unattested patterns such as *HHL arising from underlying HL (where the H tone is linked to both the first and second syllable). This is problematic since we wish to claim that couplets with the same tone on both syllables, e.g. vilit 'cat', have only a single, doubly linked tone. One way of solving this problem is to assume that tones are not linked underlyingly; they are associated to the couplet via an algorithm associating tones to tone-bearing units one-toone from left to right. This would prevent underlying IHLI from surfacing as *HHL. Pike and Ibach (1978) report that HM and MH contours do not occur on a single syllable; however, we have found two MHM words in the Yucunany dialect which do exemplify these two contours on a single syllable. Skwiia 'Santiago luxtlahuaca' has a MH contour on the first syllable and koloa 'sarape' has a HM contour on the second syllable. Thus, although HM and MH contours are rare, they are not banned outright. In addition to the unattested patterns mentioned above, we have not found the tone patterns LMH, LHL, MLM, MHL, HLM, or HMH on couplets. As far as we can tell, this is not a unified category of tone patterns that can be ruled out via any principled constraint or set of constraints. Therefore, we conclude that these are accidental gaps that may (or may not) be filled during future work on this language.
3.2 Nasalization As mentioned above, all five vowels of Mixtepec Mixtec have contrastively nasalized counterparts, although the mid vowels 6 and e~ are rare. Below are some minimal and near-minimal pairs differing in nasalization:
(9) luu ' little' uu 'yes' iii 'husband' iii 'skin' kila 'metal' Jcq'q 'talk!' nama 'soap' Fii!.m4 'wax' In addition to contrastive nasalization, we find contextual nasalization on vowels following nasal consonants, as also reported by Pike and Ibach (1978). However, in the Yucunany dialect, this contextual nasalization is non-neutralizing, so oral and nasal vowels do contrast following a nasal consonant as seen in the examples below.
(10) nama 'soap' anaa 'heart' Fii!.mfi 'wax' iFii!. 'six'
Alary Paster (lml Rosemary Beam de AZCOI1([ 67
konf 'female turkey' tzanY. 'brother's wife' mula 'mule' nuu 'face'
In couplets, vowel nasalization usually occurs in both syllables or neither, although there are also rare examples of couplets with nasalization only in the second syllable (e.g., (zany. 'brother's wife').
3.3 Glottalization Glottalization is contrastive on the first vowel of the couplet, there is apparently no contrastive glottalization on the second vowel of the couplet. Glottalization is sometimes realized as creaky voicing, but more commonly as a glottal stop following the first vowel (as reflected in our orthography, where glottalization is indicated by , after the first vowel). Below are some minimal and near-minimal pairs differing in glottalization.
(11 ) nehaa 'blue' koo 'snake' uva 'sour' ehuu 'chicken' yuva 'wild vegetable' 4. Phonological rules 4.1 Tone rules 4.1.1 Gradient Smoothing neha 'a 'salsa' ko'o 'plate' u'va 'salty' ehy"Ii 'spider' yu'va 'ice'
In LHH sequences, the first H is lowered to M. This phenomenon was also documented in Chalcatongo Mixtec by Hinton et. al. (1991). As shown below, LH-final roots, when followed by the H-toned 2sg familiar suffix, undergo Gradient Smoothing, so that the final syllable of the root surfaces with M tone .
(12) ehiil . 'fingernail' chili gu 'your fingernail' kwiii 'narrow/thin' kwiii gu 'you are narrow/thin' tikwaa 'orange' tikwaa gU 'your orange' nama 'soap' namagu 'your soap' We formalize Gradient Smoothing below. Note that we are assuming that the mora is the tone-bearing unit, though this assumption is not crucial.
(13) r ~ 1 L H H This rule del inks H between L and H. In order for this rule to yield surface [LMH], we must assume that the unlinked H is deleted via Stray Erasure, and that a vowel without a 68 1 phollologi({l/ sketch of the YlltI1I(!Y dialed ofMi ....... tepec Mixtec phonological tone is realized phonetically with Mid tone. However, we do not wish to argue that there is no phonological Mid tone; rather, we claim that there are two representations that correspond to surface Mid tone: phonologically specified Mid, and tonal non-specification.
4.1.2 Low Tone Spreading When an underlying LH sequence spans two syllables, the L is realized on both syllables, yielding surface [L.LH]. Low Tone Spreading (LTS) is also documented in Chalcatongo Mixtec (Buckley 1991). The effect of L TS can be seen in the 2sg. As shown below, the 2sg clitic surfaces with level H tone when it follows a H or M tone.
(14) lUrrz~ 'donkey' [urru gu 'your donkey' tikwiJci 'orange' tikwaa gu 'your orange' xci 'ny' 'cigarette' xci 'ny' gu 'your cigarette' Izaaku 'corral' tziJciku gu 'your corral' kaa 'metal' kGagu 'your metal' When preceded by a L tone, the 2sg gu surfaces with a LH rising tone, as seen below.
(15) chai 'chair' chai gu [tmJai uti] 'your chair' cha'iJ 'short' chci'a gu [tmJa'a uti] 'you are short' anaa 'heart' cinaa gU [an:aa uti] 'your heart' yuchi 'knife' yuchigu [yutmJi uti] 'your knife' L TS also appears to apply within lexical items. There is no contrast between LH and L.LH in roots, and as shown below, an underlying ILHI sequence surfaces as [L.LH].
(16) Ikumil ~ /tsatUi ~ [kum:ii] . [tsMuti]
We formalize LTS as shown in (17). (17) 4.2 Segmental rules 4.2.1 Nasal Place Assimilation 'four' 'box' Inama/ ~ /savi/ ~ [na' m:a, a'] [savii] 'soap' 'rain' There is no place contrast in nasals immediately preceding another consonant. The nasal is invariably pronounced at the same place of articulation as the following 'JVAIL 2004
A1(1), Pasler and Rosemary Beam de Azcona 69 consonant. This does not apparently result in any nasal place alternations, but the pattern is robust in the lexicon, as in the examples below. (18) [ndlkaa] [nda'a] [IJgwii] 'pine cone' 'hand' 'fox' [ndaaku] [IJgau] [nchaa] 'broom' 'Santa Maria Tepostlantongo' 'blue' We posit a rule of Nasal Place Assimilation to account for this pattern. In this and subsequent rules, C and V refer to Root nodes of consonants and vowels, respectively. C C [na~' , " "" "" , J (19) Place Place We have not found any cases of [mp] (or, more likely given the Post-Nasal Voicing Assimilation rule to be discussed, [mb]). However, this is not surprising since as mentioned earlier, Ipl is a marginal phoneme found only in loanwords. An alternative to this approach would be to claim that there is a prenasalized stop series, so that the word-initial onsets in the examples in (18) are single segments. We have opted to analyze these as complex N+C onsets based 0}1 evidence from verbs, which are marked by an n- prefix in the completive aspect when the root begins with It! or Its/. In these cases, the onset of the completive form of the verb surfaces as [nd] or [ndz] , respectively, and these onsets sound identical to those found in the couplets in (18). Some examples are provided below:
(20)
tiii 'I am holding'
tivii yu 'I am blowing'
tzatzii 'I am eating'
tzi'i yu 'I'm dying'
tzi'ii 'I am drinking'
4.2.2 Post-Nasal Voicing Assimilation ndiii ndiviiyu ndziztzii ndzi'iyu ndzi'ii 'I held' 'I blew' 'I ate' 'I died' 'I drank'
In the examples in (20) above, couplet-initial It! and Itzl surface as [d] and [dz], respectively, when preceded by the completive n- prefix. There is no contrast between, e.g., [nt] and [nd]; in every combination of a nasal consonant + other consonant, the entire sequence is voiced. We account for this via a Post-Nasal Voicing Assimilation rule, as formalized below.
c C ,,~ ~Oi] [-voi] (21) [nasal] ~AIL2004 70 A phollologi({J1 sketch of/he YIfClllltJlIY dialed ofAlL ..... /epee III[i:,:/!!(
4.2.3 Sonorant Gemination
Sonorant consonants are audibly lengthened intervocalically in a root, as shown in the narrow transcriptions below.
(22) kumi [kum:ii] iiii!. [in:yy] 'four' 'six' uni (un:i] 'three' k616 (k61:6] 'male turkey'
We have not systematically investigated the difference in duration between lengthened and non-lengthened sonorants, but in a typical token of vilu 'cat', the duration of medial [1] is 165 ms, compared to 119 ms for the initial [1] in a typical token of /6chi 'vulture'. To account for this pattern, we posit a rule of Sonorant Gemination that inserts a mora linked to the medial sonorant. In effect, this causes the medial sonorant to become a coda to the first syllable in addition to being the onset of the second syllable.
(23) r ~
(C) V I V
[sonorant] Couplet· 5. Morphophonology 5.1 Completive aspect allomorphy
Verb stems apparently can only begin with ItJ, Itsl, Ik!, or Isk!. As shown below, when the stem begins with Ik!, the completive aspect is marked by ni- and a complex set of tonal alternations for which we do not yet have a full analysis.
(24) kg'gyu 'I am talking' nikiJ 'gyit 'I talked' kikuit 'I am sewing' nikikuit 'I sewed' kd'vii 'I am reading' nika'vii 'I read (past)' kdnaa 'I am yelling' nikanaa 'I yelled'
Verb stems beginning in ItJ or Itsl are marked by an n- prefix in the completive form and also a floating L tone prefix, which corresponds to the low tone of the ni- allomorph.
(25) (iii 'I am holding' ndiii 'I held' tivii yu 'I am blowing' ndivii yu 'I blew' tzatzii 'I am eating' ndzatzii 'I ate' tzi'i yu 'I'm dying' ndzi'i yu 'I died' tzi'ii 'I am drinking' ndzi'ii 'I drank' '-X7 AIL 2004
, Mary Paster and Rosemary Beam de Azcona 71
When the stem begins with Isk!, the completive is not marked segmentally but takes the floating L tone prefix.
(26) sketaa 'I am running' skeetaa 'I ran' skfmaa nail 'I am throwing it' skiuinaa naa 'I threw it'
There is a difference in the way that the floating L tone associates in each of these groups. In the It/- and Its/-initial group the floating L replaces the stem-initial tone. In the Isk/-initial group the floating L concatenates to the left of the stem-initial tone. At present, we do not have an explanation for why the different stem types exhibit different tonal behaviors in the past tense.
5.2 lsg allomorphy and non-homophony
The 1 sg is ususally marked by a floating L tone that associates to the end of the root. When the root has final H tone, the L associates straightforwardly to the end of the root, yielding a HL falling tone on the final syllable with no further tone changes.
(27) nama 'soap' namaa 'my soap' kwiii 'narrow/thin' kwiiii '1 am narrowlthin' xinii 'hat' xiniii 'my hat' vilu 'cat' viluu 'my cat'
The association of the floating L (indicated by circling) to the end of the root IS schematized below.
(28) il'~, Is LH @ namaa l~ The tonal behavior ofM-final roots in the Isg depends on the preceding tones. On M-final roots where preceding tone is M or H, the floating L tone of the Isg associates to the end of the root, and the final syllable of the root surfaces with a level L tone rather than the ML falling tone that would have been expected if no tone changes occurred.
(29) la'la 'mucus' la'/a 'my mucus' ve'e 'house' ve'e 'my house' tfi'q 'relative' tfi'q 'my relative' xa 'n!:l ' ci garette ' xa" n!:,l 'my cigarette' '\'Xi'" AIL 2004
72 /1 phollologiml skelch oIlhe YIIClIlla/!Y dialecl ~/Mix/epec Mix/a Since the final M of the root does not surface in the I sg, we characterize the tone change as delinking (and subsequent deletion via Stray Erasure) of the final M of the root, as illustrated below.
(30) n"~ HM \0 ta'a f~ HM ·L Tt HL
There is an unusual exception to the above generalization, which is that, unlike other roots ending in HM, if the root has the tone pattern LHM, then the final M of the root is retained in the I sg, as in the examples in (31).
(31) yuuti 'sand' yitutii 'my sand' tzcuiku 'corral' tziuikuit 'my corral' yooso 'metate' yoosoo 'my metate' kaasa 'sister's husband' kilasaa 'my sister's husband'
This may relate to the fact that there are no LHL roots. However, it cannot result from a general ban against LHL sequences, since such sequences can be derived. As shown below, when the root has final M tone and the preceding tone is L, the M is retained in the 1 sg.
(32) kwa'a 'man's sister' kwa'aa 'my sister' srI 'leg' ' ,., S! II 'my leg' titzi 'stomach' titzii 'my stomach' kila 'metal' kaaa 'my metal'
We schematize this situation below. The floating L tone associates to the end of the root, but the M tone is not delinked. Thus, rather than LL (which might be expected based on the behavior ofHM- and MM-final roots), these roots surface with LML tone in the Isg.
(33) *kwa'a II LL
One possible analysis for the above pattern is that the Obligatory Contour Principle (OCP; Leben 1973, 1978, Goldsmith 1976) is active in this language, penalizing (derived) sequences of L tones. Deleting the M would have yielded a sequence of L tones in these words, but this could be blocked by a.version of the OCP as formalized below.
(34)
Mw)' Paster and Rosemary Beam de Azcolla 73 Until now we have discussed the behavior of roots ending in H or M tones only. Roots with final L tone take a different allomorph of the Isg marker: =yu. Some examples are provided below.
(35) ch6 'a ch61 tulu soko 'short' 'chair' 'paper' 'shoulder' ch6'ayu eMi yu tutu yu soko yu 'I am short' 'my chair' 'my paper' 'my shoulder'
It is interesting to note that this allomorphy has the effect of preventing homophony between Isg and unmarked forms. If L-final roots took the floating L tone allomorph, their 1 sg forms would be homophonous with the unmarked form. In the dialect of Mixtepec Mixtec described by Pike aand Ibach (1978), the Isg is, in fact, homophonous with the unmarked form of L-final roots. Pike and Ibach give -yu as marking the 1 sg polite; our Yucunany consultant does not distinguish polite from familiar in the Isg. Pike and Ibach (1978) appear to assume that yu is a suffix, but in Yucunany, yu can occur after noun+adjective, suggestingJhat it is not a suffix since material can intervene between yu the root. In cases where yu occurs with noun+adjective, the choice of the floating L tone vs. yu allomorph depends on the final tone of the adjective, irrespective of the tones of the noun. As shown below, when the noun has final L tone (as in tlina 'dog'), the selection of the Isg allomorph is determined by the final tone of the adjective that follows the noun.
(36) ncha'i 'black' tUna ncha 'i yU 'my black dog'
ya'a 'gray' tUna ya 'a yu 'my gray dog' nchaa 'blue' tUna nchaaa 'my blue dog' luu 'little' tUna luu luu 'my little baby dog'
As expected, when the adjective is held constant (as in the examples below using ncha'i 'black'), the tones of the noun are irrelevant to the selection ofthe Isg allomorph.
(37) kwika 'comb' . kwika ncha 'i yu 'my black comb' chai 'chair' chai ncha 'i yu 'my black chair' , ve e 'house' ve 'e ncha 'i yu 'my black house' vi/u 'cat' vilU ncha 'i yu 'my black cat' sa'maa 'clothing' sa 'maa ncha 'i yu 'my black clothing' lurru 'donkey' lUrru ncha '( yu 'my black donkey' "VV AIL 2004 74 A phollolo~~i((ll Jkfhh ~/Ihe YJlClffW!!Y dialect ofAlixlepec Mi.y/t:(
5.3 3sg vowel allomorphy
The 3s g familiar also exhibits phonologically conditioned allomorphy. The 3sg has three allomorphs whose distribution depends on the final segment of the root. On itinal roots, the 3sg is marked with -a. (38) sl'1 'leg' sl'aa 'his leg' kachii 'cotton , kachiaa 'his cotton' kwiii 'narrow' kwilaa 'he is narrow' tzi'l 'I am dying' tzi'a 'she is dying' yatzii 'small water dipper' yatziaa 'his small water dipper' xlchi 'nose' xichia 'his nose' Elsewhere, the 3sg is marked using i or naa. The -i allomorph occurs with roots ending in a, 0, and U, as shown below.
(39) saa'rnd 'clothing' saa'mil 'his clothing' vaa'a 'bad' , , vaa ,'\ 'it is bad' l ta'a 'relative' ta'i 'his relative' nda'a 'hand' nda'ii 'her hand' ko'o 'plate' ko'ii 'his plate' yo '0 'rope' yo ,I "I 'his rope' , , so 0 'ear' so" ,I."I 'his ear' rna tzd 'ny' 'grandmother' rna tzd'nl 'his grandmother' ku'u 'woman's sister' ku'i 'her sister' The -naa allomorph occurs with roots ending in a, 0, e, and u.
(40) ncha'a "salsa' nchd'a naa 'his salsa' yosoo 'grassy plain' yosoo naa 'his grassy plain' xito 'uncle' xito naa 'his uncle' xioo 'dress' xioo naa 'her dress' yoo 'drinking vessel' yoo naa 'his drinking vessel' ve'e 'house' ve 'e nail 'his house' kiche 'e 'bone' kiche 'e naa 'his bone' kweee 'slow' kweee nail 'he is slow'
The -i and -naa allomorphs overlap in their distribution, since both can occur with roots ending in a, 0, and u. We have not been able to establish a generalization regarding the use of -I vs. -naa. However, one clear generalization regarding the 3sg (familiar) is that roots ending in Iii never take the -i allomorph. This has the effect of preventing homophony with the plain form of roots ending in L-toned Iii and with the Isg form of underlyingly HM- and MM-toned roots ending in Iii.

6. Conclusion In this paper we have provided a brief description of the phonological system of the Yucunany dialect of Mixtepec Mixtec as we currently understand it. Some of our most interesting results have been in the domain of phonologically based allomorphy. In particular, there are two categories (lsg and 3sg) where allomorphy has the effect of preventing homophony with other morphologically related forms. The exact distribution of these allomorphs and the historical origin of the allomorphy are part of our ongoing research on this dialect. Other phonological topics for future research include the distribution of nasalized vowels and patterns of loanword adaptation. Notes + We are very grateful to our consultant Tisu'ma X for his time and patience. We also thank Wendianne Eller, Rich Rhodes, and Leanne Hinton for their various contributions to this work. This research has been funded by the Survey of California and Other Indian Languages at UC Berkeley. I We have found a small number of apparent counterexamples which we suspect are either synchronically or historically multimorphemic or borrowings since they have more than two syllables, e.g. Kanama 'Cafiama' (a toponym).
